content1.EN:
[CAMPUSCLUE]Under FERPA, your institution can determine when rights begin for new and incoming students (e.g., date of enrollment, date of admission, etc.). However, FERPA states that "student status" cannot begin any later than the first day of classes.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • In higher education, FERPA protects eligible students

    • Higher education refers to postsecondary school—an educational institution (usually a college or university) which is attended after graduation from secondary school or high school.

    • An eligible student is defined as a student who has reached 18 years of age OR is attending a postsecondary institution.

Under FERPA, students have four guaranteed rights regarding their education records:

  1. Right to Inspect and Review

  2. Right to Seek to Amend

  3. Right Over Disclosure

  4. Right to File a Complaint

[CAMPUSCLUE]Students should submit official written requests to the appropriate office in order to review their records. Also, schools often require the student to identify which records are being requested for inspection. Requests for access must be granted within 45 days of the request.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

Students have the right to:

  • inspect and review [TERM education records]Any record which contains information that is personally identifiable to a student AND is maintained by the institution. Discussed in detail in Module 4.[/TERM]

  • be informed of the procedure for HOW to inspect and review their education records.

title.EN: Right to Inspect and Review - Inaccessible Information

content1.EN:
Students CANNOT review the following information which may be part of their records:

  • information about other students

  • financial records of parents

  • [TERM confidential letters of recommendation]letters that the student has waived his right to inspect and are related to admission, application for employment, or honorary recognition[/TERM]

title.EN: Right to Inspect and Review - Withholding Rights

content1.EN:
[CAMPUSCLUE]Even though your school cannot withhold the viewing of transcripts, it is not required to provide students with copies of records (including transcripts) unless it's the only means for the student to inspect the record. In these cases, the institution may include a watermark across the document stating "outstanding financial obligation exists," or "unofficial transcripts," for example.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Schools are not allowed to withhold students' right to inspect records.

  • NOT permitted under FERPA:

    • Requiring search and retrieval fees

    • Withholding the viewing of transcripts until an outstanding financial obligation is paid

[CAMPUSCLUE ALIGN=RIGHT]Your school is permitted by FERPA to determine the appropriate processing time to respond to amendment requests. However, FERPA does acknowledge that this be "within a reasonable time."[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Students have the right to:

    • seek amendment to education records believed to be inaccurate or misleading

    • be informed of the procedure for HOW to amend education records

  • Students should submit a written statement detailing objections.

title.EN: Right to Seek to Amend - Appeal Process

content1.EN:
[CAMPUSCLUE]Institutions should never keep anonymous records that make it impossible to trace the source and therefore amend a student's record.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

  • Student must be:

    • given the opportunity for a formal hearing AND

    • be advised of the appeal process

  • Hearing requirements:

    • held within a reasonable amount of time

    • give notice of the date, time, and place

    • conducted by someone who doesn't have direct interest in the outcome

    • give fair opportunity to provide evidence

    • provide decisions in writing that include a summary of evidence and reasons for the decision

  • If the outcome of the hearing is unfavorable to the student, the contested part of the record must be maintained and disclosed along with the record for as long as the record is kept.

title.EN: Right to Seek to Amend - Exceptions

content1.EN:
[CAMPUSCLUE]FERPA does not dictate guidelines for handling amendments to grades. Your school should establish its own policy to deal with grade disputes.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

According to FERPA, institutions are NOT required to amend the following:

  • Grades

  • Records not created by the school (transfered from another entity and are now part of the education record)

    • objections must be directed to the source of the records

[CAMPUSCLUE]Be careful when listing names of students and posting group photos. A student may have requested disclosure restrictions. When in doubt about releasing information, a good practice is to ask for prior written consent.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

Students have some control over the [TERM disclosure]to make known, reveal, or share[/TERM] of [TERM personally identifiable information]the kind of information or data from which the identity of a specific person can be determined. For example, student’s name, place of birth, or SSN. This concept is discussed in detail in Module 4[/TERM] from their records. Students:

  • must provide a written request to restrict disclosure

  • can request the following be withheld:

    1. Directory information – Information not generally considered harmful or an invasion of privacy if disclosed.

    2. ALL information regarding the student. This is sometimes referred to as a "FERPA Restriction."

[CAMPUSCLUE]FERPA restrictions can be tricky for both the education official and the student. For example, if an employer calls to verify that the student is in attendance, the school must say there is no information on that particular student. This can be embarrassing and cause employment issues. This is an example of why students must be counseled before requesting such a restriction.[/CAMPUSCLUE]

Students may request that NO information whatsoever be disclosed.

  • In these cases, the student's attendance and entire existence at the institution may never be confirmed to the public.

  • These are very rare student requests and require counseling and extenuating circumstances such as being in the witness protection program, a celebrity, or a stalking victim.

Students have the right to file a complaint concerning alleged FERPA compliance failures. Complaints must:

  • be submitted in writing to the [TERM FPCO]See the address in the “Resources and References” section of the course syllabus.[/TERM]

  • contain specific allegations of fact and provide reasonable cause to believe that a violation has occurred

[CASESTUDY Kevin Student felt that his school did not properly guard his education records after his professor announced in front of the entire class that he was failing the course. After being publicly humiliated, Kevin tried to sue the school for violating his privacy. Can Kevin use FERPA to bring this suit against the institution?]No. There is no private cause of action under FERPA, meaning that FERPA cannot be the basis of complaint in a private suit. This issue was recently confirmed by the U.S. Supreme Court in Gonzaga University and Robert S. League v. John Doe. Kevin could try to pursue action under a common Law remedy, such as libel or slander.[/CASESTUDY]
